Article.ArticleTitle: Outcome of Budd-Chiari Syndrome (BCS) patients treated with direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) - an Austrian multicenter study.

Abstract.AbstractText: Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) may simplify management of Budd-Chiari Syndrome (BCS). Here we report our experience with off-label use of DOACs for anticoagulation in BCS.
Safety of DOAC vs. vitamin K antagonist (VKA) treatment as well as associated clinical outcomes were retrospectively assessed in 47 BCS patients treated at 6 Austrian centers.

Mean age at study inclusion was 37.9±14.0 years and mean MELD was 13.1±5.1. Overall, 63.8% (n=30) had decompensated liver disease, and 87.2% (n=41) showed clinical signs of portal hypertension. During a median follow-up of 82.5 (IQR: 43.1-121.8) months, 43 patients (91.5%) received anticoagulation alone or following interventional treatment including 22 patients (46.8%) treated with DOACs (edoxaban: 10, apixaban: 4, rivaroxaban: 3, dabigatran: 3, more than one DOAC sequentially: 2) for a median of 24.4 (5.7-35.1) months. While 72.7% of patients (16/22) were switched from LMWH (n=12) or VKA (n=4) to DOAC after disease stabilization/improvement, 27.3% (6/22) of BCS patients were initially treated with DOAC. 'Complete response' (EASL criteria) was achieved or maintained in 14/22 (63.6%) patients, 'ongoing response' in 2 patients, while disease progressed in 6 patients (including 2 patients with HCC). Four major spontaneous bleedings (18.2%; incidence rate 8.8/100 patient years; n=2 upper-GI-bleeding, n=1 lower-GI-bleeding, n=1 HCC rupture), 7 minor bleedings and one major procedure-related bleeding (4.5%; 2.2/100 patient years) occurred during DOAC therapy. Overall transplant-free survival was 91.6% at 5 years.
DOACs seem to be effective and safe for long-term anticoagulation in patients with BCS, but confirmation by larger prospective studies is needed.
